title: Case Study 9: Sudden Tinnitus and High-Frequency Loss
chief_complaint: I've had severe ringing in my ears for the past 2 weeks. My hearing seems fine, but I occasionally confuse words and have a harder time in noisy environments.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Severe tinnitus, difficulty hearing in noise
problem_summary.functional_impact: Occasional confusion of words, difficulty in noisy environments
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of tinnitus and hearing status

history.present_illness: Patient reports severe tinnitus for the past 2 weeks. Subjectively feels hearing is fine but notes difficulty in noise.
history.otologic_history: None reported prior to current episode.
history.medical_psych_history: Recently treated for a severe urinary tract infection; cannot recall the name of the medication.
history.patient_goals: Determine cause of ringing and hearing difficulties.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Standard PTA indicates normal hearing sensitivity. However, high-frequency PTA (2, 4, 8 kHz) is elevated compared to the standard PTA, suggesting a high-frequency slope. Extended high-frequency testing reveals significant loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds align with pure tone averages. Word Recognition Scores are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A) bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function. Curves overlap with peaks near 0 daPa.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAEs)
tests.key_findings: DPOAEs are present and robust from 0.5 to 4 kHz. Amplitudes drop sharply and become indistinguishable from the noise floor at frequencies above 4-6 kHz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient demonstrates normal hearing sensitivity in the conventional frequency range (250-8000 Hz), supported by excellent speech recognition scores and normal middle ear function. However, extended high-frequency testing reveals a significant bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (no response at 12-16 kHz) and reduced DPOAEs above 4 kHz. These findings, combined with the history of recent antibiotic treatment for a severe infection, are consistent with ototoxicity.
counseling_points: Explain that while standard hearing is normal, the ringing and difficulty in noise are likely caused by damage to the very high-pitch hearing cells.
Discuss the likelihood that the medication used for the UTI (possibly an aminoglycoside) caused this damage (ototoxicity).
Advise on hearing conservation strategies, as the ears may be more susceptible to noise damage.
Discuss tinnitus management strategies, such as sound enrichment or masking, since the ringing is the primary complaint.
notes_for_actor: Portray a young adult who is confused because they feel they can hear fine generally, but the ringing is very bothersome.
Emphasize the difficulty in noisy environments despite 'normal' hearing in quiet.
Be unsure about the specific medication name but confirm it was for a severe infection.
